Thanks for narrowing this down and following up on the Restlet angle! 
I've just looked at the Restlet FileClientHelper code, and it looks like 
it should be able to use a better (raw, not line-by-line) fallback copy 
operation.

Some thoughts on workarounds in the meantime:

 From the comments there and in File.renameTo, it seems notable reasons 
it might fail are (1) can't rename between filesystems; and (2) 
destination file exists.

What filesystem(s) are you using? If you can step through the relevant 
code, can you see if Restlet's 'tmp' file is in a surprising (perhaps 
different-filesystem) place?

We do expect this PUT operation to usually replace an existing file, in 
which case the JVM process will need all necessary permissions to do 
that. If in fact the fallback code works, it seems it must -- but 
perhaps there is a permissions difference whereby the rename can't work 
but a write-over can?

One other intermittent IO trouble that sometimes comes up -- though far 
more often on Windows, which doesn't seem a factor here: memory-mapped 
files may be locked against desired operations until some indeterminate 
time after close()ing, waiting for memory-mapped buffer cleanup. (For 
example <http://bugs.sun.com/bugdatabase/view_bug.do?bug_id=4715154>.) I 
don't think this is your problem but thought I'd mention it just in case.

- Gordon @ IA

Daniel Truemper wrote:
> Hi,
> 
>> Hmm that is very odd. Here I was able to send arbitrary data, in utf-8, latin1 and raw binary, and it always comes back unchanged. 
> 
> I finally found some time to debug this. A small bug within Restlet. I have already submitted a Patch [1]!
> 
> Basically a File.renameTo does not work and a BufferedReader is reading into a BufferedWriter. When writing the "\n" is missing... The question remains, why the renameTo did not work?! Permissions should not prevent this...
> 
> Best
> Daniel
> 
> [1]: http://restlet.tigris.org/issues/show_bug.cgi?id=1018
